titleStmt.title: M54, 8 of 11. [Anon: With that a joyous fellow issued]. Typescript fragment, 3 fols.
titleStmt.author: Virginia Woolf

publicationStmt.authority: The Estate of Virginia Woolf, administered by the Society of Authors

msIdentifier.repository: Henry W. and Albert A. Berg Collection of English and American Literature

physDesc.p: M54, 8 of 11. [Anon: With that a joyous fellow issued]. Typescript fragment, 3 fols.

N.B.: This is one of eleven sub-fragments identified in the Berg Collection's M54. [Anon: The printing press brought the past into existence...]. Typescript fragments, unsigned and undated, 35 fols. I have determined pagination and sequencing based on subject matter. M54 as curated by the Berg Collection is available as part of 'The Digital Anon' and can be found at [LINK].

handNote.p: Holograph writing by the documents' main hand, Virginia Woolf

correction.p: Apparent errors have been explicitly corrected in sic / corr tags, wrapped in a choice element.

interpretation.p: Names and references to places and literary works have been wrapped in rs tags which link to annotations and secondary material.

projectDesc.p: Text encoded as part of 'The Digital "Anon": A Digital Genetic Edition of Virginia Woolf's Final Essays'. This project, funded by Leverhulme Grant ECF-2022-602, seeks to construct a TEI-XML based digital edition of the drafts of 'Anon' and 'The Reader', among the final documents Woolf wrote before her death.

div.p: With that a joyous fellowship iissued (issued) Of misnterls (minstrels) making goodly merriment With wanton bardes and Rhymers impudent

The word remind us that if the great Elizabethan house, or looks to us out of proportion, xmxmx a derelict among th (the) bungalows, it is because the connection between it and the village is lost. If we could see the house as it was in time we should see tracks raying out from the great house across the fields to the cottage, to the farm, even to the hovel. War connected them. Armour, if the enemy came was stored in the church. The young men practised the great English art of the long bow. Also, there was the other fight, the pertual (perpetual) fight with nature. They must together plough and sow if the winter were not to starve them. This connection xxx between master and man is painfully and minutely recorded in the medieval letters. It is th (the) staple of the whole correspondence. But there was also the other less visible connection--the common belief. That bond between the different houses has been grown over, like the track along which the rode to . No one drives there now. [illeg.]. But whe (when) came to that track led from house to house. It led to the village green. It led to the tree; to the well. In the spring they danced round the Maypole; at midsummer they lit the bon fire on the hill; at Christmas the mummers acted their dumb show; the boys came wassailing xmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxm

at Harvest time the God was worshipped in the sheaf of corn; how thxmXmxmxmmxmx the God was in the
ay (bay) tree--how in the dances and songs that childre (children) sing the old Gods were worshipped, and served. In these dressings up at thxmxmxx midsummer, at Christmas the En lish (English) rememberig (remembering) the Gods who were there when the stones were set on end at , at , celebrated their gods; and at the same tiem (time) gave shape to to the desire to cease, for that one day, from the pertual (perpetual) fight; to be free; to be som
tjing (something); to act in their own persons the inner joy; to make something which had no reason, no use. The schloars (scholars) tell us that though t e e (the) actors, presumably because they slipped from the common task, and often made mock of it, were despsed (despised) despised, yet the great had so much of the common desire in them that Kings and Queens must have their minstresl (minstrels), ther (their) dancers and singers. Even the Church, conscious as the
preists (priests) were that it was not theirGod (their God) but some pagan
wh (who) was thus hinoured (honoured), could not suppress the minstrels and and the rhymers, the mummers, the jugglers, the bear leaders who came into the village, who acted t eir (their) parts in the churchyard.

This was the other bo d (bond) between the great house and the cottage. In the noble, as in the pe asnt (peasant), a half conscious, anonymous voice mur ured (murmured) of. The well and the tree were still hanuted (haunted); Some o d (old) woman in her hovel was still to the King even the vessel of an unclean spirit. She mowed (mewed) and mobbed and plucked her chin. When the pilliwinks were appied (applied) to her, she confessed how she had

how she sailed in a sive (sieve) singing to the she confessed to how she had throw (thrown) a cat into the sea and
rasied (raised) a storm that had sunk the kings ships.
